title: Electric force - on 10 uC from -10 uC and 20 uC

content.question: Three point charges are located along a straight line, as shown in the figure. The <math alttext="negative 10 microcoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>μC</mi></math> and <math alttext="positive 20 microcoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>20</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>μC</mi></math> point charges are <math alttext="0.50 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and <math alttext="1.00 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, respectively, from the <math alttext="positive 10 microcoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>μC</mi></math> point charge on the far left. What is the magnitude of the electrostatic force on the <math alttext="positive 10 microcoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>μC</mi></math> point charge exerted by the other two point charges?
